questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of pain in her right knee. The pain is worse at the end of the day and when she walks. She says that it has become difficult for her to walk up the flight of stairs to reach her apartment. She has hypertension. Her sister has rheumatoid arthritis. She drinks two to three beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and a multivitamin. She appears anxious. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (202 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 135/83 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The right knee is not tender or erythematous; range of motion is limited. Crepitus is heard on flexion and extension of the knee. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 16 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections may be administered in patients with severe osteoarthritis to provide short-term pain relief. However, glucocorticoid injections are only indicated if active joint inflammation is present or if nonpharmacological and first-line pharmacological therapy (NSAIDs) do not provide sufficient relief to overcome functional impairment.

B) CORRECT:

A weight loss program is one of the most important general measures to relieve symptoms in patients with osteoarthritis who are overweight or obese. Osteoarthritis is the most common joint disorder in the US. Its incidence increases with age and it commonly affects women over the age of 50 years. The knees are the most commonly affected joints, followed by the hands and hips. Because there are only a few modifiable risk factors in patients with osteoarthritis, including obesity and excessive joint loading or overuse, causal treatment is limited and weight loss is the most effective step in management at this time.

If lifestyle changes (moderate exercise, weight loss) and physical therapy do not improve symptoms or patients have persistent pain, pharmacological treatment may be required. First-line pharmacological treatment consists of NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen).

C) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is commonly performed in patients with joint effusions to evaluate synovial fluid for crystals (e.g., in crystal-induced arthropathies like gout), leukocytes, and gram-staining (e.g., presence of bacteria in septic arthritis). Patients with both septic arthritis and crystal-induced arthropathies can present with arthralgias and a limited range of motion. However, septic arthritis is usually associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever), while both conditions are typically associated with an acute onset, significant swelling, and erythema of the joint. The patient has none of these features.

D) INCORRECT:

Total joint replacement (endoprosthesis) is the treatment of choice in patients with osteoarthritis if conservative and interventional measures fail. But this patient has not received any treatment yet, meaning total joint replacement is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA typically manifests with joint pain, as in this patient. She might also have a genetic predisposition given her sister's history. However, RA most commonly affects small finger joints, and patients present with symmetrical swelling of the joints and morning stiffness that typically improves with activity. This patient has none of these symptoms, so RA is very unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the preferred method to evaluate soft tissue and cartilage of the knee. MRI can show precisely what damage has been done to the soft tissue within the knee (e.g., meniscus rupture, cruciate ligament injury). MRI is not indicated in the majority of patients with osteoarthritis unless an underlying pathology such as meniscus rupture is suspected.
questions.hint: Knee pain that is worse at the end of the day, crepitus, and limited range of motion in a patient with obesity, combined with osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and joint space narrowing on x-ray, indicate osteoarthritis of the knee.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with progressive left hip pain comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One year ago, he was diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the left hip. Since then, he has had an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss after changing to a vegetarian diet, regular swimming, and physical therapy. The pain worsens when he climbs stairs, which makes it increasingly difficult for him to reach his apartment located on the second floor. Over the last few weeks, he gradually increased the frequency of diclofenac intake but says that even a daily intake does not provide complete pain relief. He asks for a treatment that will lead to a long-term improvement of his symptoms. He has no history of major medical illness. His only other medication is pantoprazole. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is 179 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Physical examination of the left hip shows crepitus, a limited internal rotation, and pain with full flexion and extension. An x-ray of the left hip shows joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis and cysts. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopic hip debridement may be used in the treatment of a labral tear or femoroacetabular impingement of the hip, but it is generally not recommended in the treatment of either hip or knee OA because of the lack of evidence supporting its benefits.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections may be administered in patients with severe OA to provide short-term pain relief. However, they are not a long-term option. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate for this patient, who asks for long-term improvement of his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Walking aids, such as a walker, cane, or crutches (used on the healthy, unaffected side) may be used in patients with hip OA and severe pain and/or as fall prevention. However, there is no evidence that walking aids reduce pain in patients with hip OA, nor are walking aids a good option for patients like this one, who are physically active.

D) INCORRECT:

Fentanyl patches have a high analgesic potency and are used to treat insufficiently controlled chronic pain, which is seen in this patient. While nonopioid analgesics in conjunction with nonpharmacologic measures are an important part of pain management in patients with OA, opioids should generally be avoided, especially as a long-term solution, because of potential adverse effects (e.g., dizziness, nausea, addictive potential).

E) CORRECT:

Total hip arthroplasty is recommended in patients with hip OA who have experienced inadequate relief using conservative measures (physical therapy, exercise, weight loss, pain medication), there is evidence of advanced OA (e.g., severe pain, radiological signs of osteoarthritis), and symptoms impact the patient's daily life significantly, as seen here. In addition, this patient has no evidence of contraindications to surgery (e.g., active infection, major medical illness).

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections can be used as second-line therapy for short-term pain relief (e.g., while waiting for surgery).
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Marked narrowing of the weight-bearing regions of the acetabulofemoral joint spaces (yellow lines) is accompanied by femoral head and acetabular sclerosis (green overlay), subchondral cyst formation (examples indicated by white dashed outlines), and osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay). The femoral heads show superolateral migration and loss of normal sphericity.
questions.hint: Long-term improvement of osteoarthritis (OA) of the hip joint requires treating the cause rather than the symptoms.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, and stage 3 chronic kidney disease presents for evaluation of progressive right-medial knee pain during the past 3 years. The pain is exacerbated by walking or climbing stairs but improves with rest. The patient reports minimal relief with acetaminophen.
Physical examination reveals a stable knee with a varus deformity, crepitus, a small effusion without warmth, and mild tenderness over the medial joint line. Range of motion is reasonably well preserved, although there is joint stiffness with >90 degrees of passive flexion. A radiograph reveals moderate medial-joint-space narrowing and subchondral sclerosis.
Which one of the following management approaches is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

With a varus deformity caused by medial cartilage loss, unloading of the medial compartment can be attempted with a laterally elevated shoe insert, although the evidence to support this approach is not strong. A medially elevated wedge insert would be expected to increase load on the medial compartment and could potentially exacerbate symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Pain and reduced mobility from knee osteoarthritis often cause atrophy of the quadriceps. Physical therapy aimed at strengthening the quadriceps muscles can be safe and effective.

With a varus deformity caused by medial cartilage loss, unloading of the medial compartment can be attempted with a laterally elevated shoe insert, although the evidence to support this approach is not strong.

Key learning point: The initial approach to knee osteoarthritis includes analgesia and strategies to stabilize the knee, including physical therapy to strengthen the quadriceps muscles.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucosamine alone did not significantly reduce pain from knee osteoarthritis in a large randomized controlled trial, although the combination with chondroitin sulfate did modestly reduce the pain of moderate-to-severe osteoarthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Chondroitin sulfate alone did not significantly reduce pain from knee osteoarthritis in a large randomized controlled trial, although the combination with chondroitin sulfate did modestly reduce the pain of moderate-to-severe osteoarthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Viscosupplementation with intra-articular hyaluronan may have some benefit, but this issue remains controversial, and conservative measures should be tried first.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with left-knee pain that has been worsening for the past year. His BMI is 40. The patient says that he has significant discomfort in his left knee when he walks or stands for long periods and that the pain worsens when he descends a flight of stairs. He is concerned that his right knee may be starting to bother him as well.
Bilateral standing radiographs of the knees reveal mild-to-moderate medial joint-space narrowing on the left, but normal findings on the right.
What is the most appropriate long-term strategy for preventing progression of this patient's disease process?

choices.text: Consult with an orthopedic surgeon to schedule left total-knee arthroplasty
Start ibuprofen 600 mg two to three times daily
Start physical therapy once a week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Minimizing activity may reduce pain in the short term but is unlikely to prevent progression.

B) CORRECT:

Obesity is one of the strongest modifiable risk factors for the development of osteoarthritis (OA). A longitudinal study showed that among people with unilateral knee pain, the risk for contralateral knee osteoarthritis increased by 6.5% for each additional 5 kg of weight. In another study, participants in the highest BMI tertile had 8.6 times the odds of developing radiographic and symptomatic osteoarthritis as participants in the lowest BMI tertile. Weight loss has been shown to reduce knee pain in patients with radiographic OA. Weight loss is, therefore, the best long-term management strategy for this patient.

Whether weight loss slows the radiographic progression of OA once it is apparent is unclear. However, in this patient, weight loss has the prospect of reducing pain and reducing the likelihood that OA will develop in the knee that is currently asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic.

Key learning point: In patients with obesity and osteoarthritis of the knees, weight loss should be recommended as a long-term strategy to reduce and prevent worsening of arthritis symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Total knee arthroplasty is warranted only if osteoarthritis symptoms persist despite appropriate conservative management, and many surgeons would be reluctant to operate on a patient at such a young age or with severe obesity.

D) INCORRECT:

Regular use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs may reduce pain in the short term but is unlikely to prevent progression. In addition, long-term use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents may be associated with adverse effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy might help to strengthen the quadriceps muscles but is unlikely to prevent progression unless accompanied by weight loss.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes presents with pain in the left hip and anterior left groin that has slowly worsened during the past 2 years. The pain worsens with walking and improves with rest. It does not radiate into the leg, low back, or buttocks and is not accompanied by any leg weakness, numbness, or tingling. The patient does not recall any preceding trauma and states that she does not experience fevers, night sweats, or unintended weight loss.
Which one of the following maneuvers during physical examination is most likely to reproduce this patient’s pain?

choices.text: Direct pressure over the lateral hip

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis, the most common disorder of the hip joint, frequently causes anterior hip or groin pain that worsens with weight-bearing or exercise and improves with rest. This pain can usually be reproduced by internal rotation of the hip with the leg extended — a maneuver that narrows the space between the femoral head and acetabulum.

The FABER test would be another reasonable physical examination maneuver in this case, if the patient can tolerate it. While the patient is lying supine, the leg is placed in a figure-4 position (Flexion, ABduction and External Rotation of the affected leg, so that the ankle of that leg is on top of the opposite knee). Anterior hip/groin pain or limitation of the range of motion constitutes a positive test and indicates hip pathology, although a FABER test can also cause pain with iliopsoas spasm or sacroiliac disease (in the contralateral buttock). Patients with advanced hip osteoarthritis may not be able to tolerate a FABER test.

Key learning point: Osteoarthritis of the hip causes anterior hip and groin pain that can be reproduced by internal rotation of the hip.

B) INCORRECT:

Straight-leg-raise tests are more likely to elicit pain related to lumbar radiculopathy by stretching or impinging vulnerable nerves.

C) INCORRECT:

Straight-leg-raise tests are more likely to elicit pain related to lumbar radiculopathy by stretching or impinging vulnerable nerves.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the hip is a nonspecific maneuver that may be well tolerated even with severe hip osteoarthritis because it does not effectively move the femoral head toward the acetabulum.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct pressure over the lateral hip may aggravate pain caused by greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) or gluteus medius tendonitis but does not affect hip pain that is due to osteoarthritis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man reports a 7-week history of progressive pain and swelling in his left knee that developed after he returned from a sightseeing trip to Cambodia. The pain is exacerbated by walking and is relieved by rest. There is no locking of the knee. During the past year, the patient has noted morning stiffness affecting his legs that resolves within 15 minutes after waking up. He reports no other recent trauma, injury, or illness.
On physical examination, his temperature is 36.9°C, his blood pressure is 132/72 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute. There is a large left-knee effusion without warmth or erythema. Varus deformity of the left knee is noted, and range of motion in extension or flexion is limited by pain. No joint-line tenderness is found. A McMurray test is negative for any clicking in the medial compartment. The remainder of the musculoskeletal examination is normal.
Plain radiography of the left knee reveals a large effusion, narrowing of the medial joint space, and osteophytes arising from the patellofemoral and tibiofemoral joints.
Arthrocentesis is performed, and a 25-mL synovial-fluid sample is clear yellow with a leukocyte count of 300 per mm3 and a differential of 92% lymphocytes and 8% neutrophils.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis, caused by bacterial infection, results in purulent-appearing synovial fluid, a leukocyte count that is always inflammatory and usually in the range of 50,000 to 150,000 per mm3, and a strong neutrophil predominance.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is unlikely in the absence of inflammatory synovial fluid. Rheumatoid arthritis also usually features morning stiffness lasting >60 minutes and most often involves the small joints of the hands and feet.

C) INCORRECT:

Pes anserinus pain syndrome occurs as an overuse syndrome of the knee and is often exacerbated by pes planus (flat feet). Pain can be difficult for patients to localize symptomatically, but physical examination identifies focal tenderness at the pes anserine, a convergence of three tendons (sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus) at the proximal medial tibia, 2 to 3 cm distal to the knee joint line.

D) INCORRECT:

Crystalline arthropathies manifest with inflammatory synovial fluid along with the presence of monosodium urate or calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals. Some patients with osteoarthritis have deposition of CPP in the cartilage of affected joints (known as chondrocalcinosis) and are therefore at risk for acute CPP crystal arthritis (pseudogout), but the fluid in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis is inflammatory.

E) CORRECT:

The patient’s symptoms are typical of an osteoarthritis flare. The principal symptom of osteoarthritis is pain, which usually increases with activity and improves with rest. In more advanced cases, pain may become persistent and occur at rest or at night. Morning stiffness that resolves in less than 30 minutes is also common in patients with osteoarthritis, although some patients describe recurrence of stiffness after a period of inactivity, known as the gelling phenomenon.

The joints most commonly affected in osteoarthritis are the knees, the hips, and the distal interphalangeal and first carpometacarpal joints of the hands. Examination of an affected knee may be normal but is often notable for tenderness on palpation at the joint line, limited range of motion, crepitus, and/or joint effusion. The major radiographic features include joint-space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts.

There is a broad differential diagnosis for acute or subacute monoarticular knee pain and swelling. If a patient’s symptoms, findings on physical examination, and radiographic evidence are suggestive of an osteoarthritic flare, arthrocentesis can be done to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes, such as a septic arthritis or crystalline arthropathy.

The synovial fluid in patients with osteoarthritis is typically noninflammatory, with a leukocyte count up to 2000 per mm3, a predominance of lymphocytes, and <25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

Key learning point: Joint effusions related to osteoarthritis typically have noninflammatory fluid with leukocyte counts in the range of 200 to 2000 cells per mm3.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with obesity, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia reports a 2-year history of pain in his right knee, which he describes as aching, medial, and deep. The pain occurs with any activity, such that he must walk with a cane, and it occasionally wakes him from sleep. He also reports morning stiffness that lasts for about 15 minutes. He denies other joint pain or any history of falls.
His current vital signs are normal. Examination of the right knee reveals a small, cool effusion, medial joint-line tenderness, crepitus, and reduced range of motion on flexion and extension. Examination of the left knee and the hips is unremarkable.
Which one of the following tests should be ordered next for this patient?

choices.text: Anteroposterior, lateral, and sunrise plain radiographs of the right knee
Weight-bearing plain radiographs of both knees

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the knee is not particularly useful in diagnosing OA.

B) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis can be helpful in ruling out inflammatory or infectious causes of knee pain. In this case, however, the chronicity of the patient’s symptoms, the small size of the effusion, and the lack of erythema and warmth at the knee suggest a noninflammatory arthritis. Arthrocentesis, if done, would reveal noninflammatory fluid (leukocyte count, <2000 per mm3) without crystals and with negative cultures.

C) INCORRECT:

Non-weight-bearing films may not accurately detect joint-space loss. The sunrise view is used to evaluate for OA or malalignment involving the patella.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the knee is useful for planning surgical intervention or to detect meniscal or ligament injury. Although MRI will detect OA earlier than plain radiographs would, it is usually not indicated for the clinical diagnosis of OA.

E) CORRECT:

Tenderness to palpation, restricted range of motion, a small, cool effusion, and crepitus are all common findings in knee osteoarthritis (OA). OA, the most common cause of joint pain in people older than age 65, causes severe disability. It develops insidiously over many years of cartilage loss, leading to joint-space narrowing and osteophyte formation. Pain typically occurs with activity and resolves with rest; patients report morning stiffness, which should resolve in <30 minutes. Patients with advanced disease may have pain at rest or at night.

Although imaging is not needed to diagnose OA, radiography is indicated in this case because of the presence of nocturnal knee pain. A weight-bearing radiograph of both knees is the optimal method to detect joint-space narrowing in knee OA, even when symptoms are unilateral.

Key learning point: The best initial imaging test to diagnose knee osteoarthritis is weight-bearing bilateral radiographs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes presents with pain in the left hip and anterior left groin that has slowly worsened during the past 2 years. The pain worsens with walking and improves with rest. It does not radiate into the leg, low back, or buttocks and is not accompanied by any leg weakness, numbness, or tingling. The patient does not recall any preceding trauma and states that she does not experience fevers, night sweats, or unintended weight loss. Which one of the following maneuvers during physical examination is most likely to reproduce this patient’s pain?

choices.text: Direct pressure over the lateral hip

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's hip pain can be reproduced by internal rotation of the hip with the leg extended — a maneuver that narrows the space between the femoral head and acetabulum.

The FABER test would be another reasonable physical examination maneuver in this case, if the patient can tolerate it. While the patient is lying supine, the leg is placed in a figure-4 position (Flexion, ABduction and External Rotation of the affected leg, so that the ankle of that leg is on top of the opposite knee). Anterior hip/groin pain or limitation of the range of motion constitutes a positive test and indicates hip pathology, although a FABER test can also cause pain with iliopsoas spasm or sacroiliac disease (in the contralateral buttock). Patients with advanced hip osteoarthritis may not be able to tolerate a FABER test.

Key learning point: Osteoarthritis of the hip causes anterior hip and groin pain that can be reproduced by internal rotation of the hip.

B) INCORRECT:

Straight-leg-raise tests are more likely to elicit pain related to lumbar radiculopathy by stretching or impinging vulnerable nerves.

C) INCORRECT:

Straight-leg-raise tests are more likely to elicit pain related to lumbar radiculopathy by stretching or impinging vulnerable nerves.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the hip is a nonspecific maneuver that may be well tolerated even with severe hip osteoarthritis because it does not effectively move the femoral head toward the acetabulum.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct pressure over the lateral hip may aggravate pain caused by greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) or gluteus medius tendonitis but does not affect hip pain that is due to osteoarthritis.
questions.hint: Anterior hip or groin pain that worsens with weight-bearing or exercise and improves with rest raises suspicion for osteoarthritis, the most common disorder of the hip joint.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with gradually worsening pain in his left knee over the past year. He notices stiffness after resting that subsides within a few minutes of movement. He denies acute injury or significant swelling but occasionally hears a “crunching” sound with motion. He has difficulty climbing stairs and has started limiting his physical activities. He has tried over-the-counter NSAIDs with partial relief. His BMI is 30 kg/m2. Examination shows mild joint-line tenderness, limited flexion, and minimal effusion without redness or warmth.
Which of the following initial investigations is most appropriate to evaluate his left knee symptoms?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the knee
Weight-bearing plain radiograph of the knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Computed tomography (CT) is useful for detailed bony imaging, particularly in complex fractures or preoperative planning. In this case, the presentation suggests osteoarthritis, best evaluated initially with plain radiographs, which effectively demonstrate degenerative changes without the higher radiation exposure of CT.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is effective for assessing soft tissue structures and detecting effusions. However, it is limited in evaluating bony changes and joint space narrowing associated with osteoarthritis, which are better visualized with plain radiographs.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is ideal for visualizing soft tissue structures like ligaments and menisci, useful in suspected internal derangements. However, the clinical features of gradual knee pain, transient stiffness, and crepitus suggest osteoarthritis, where plain radiographs are preferred for initial evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Weight-bearing plain radiographs are the first-line investigation for suspected osteoarthritis due to their ability to reveal structural changes such as joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis. These changes correlate with the clinical presentation of gradual onset knee pain, brief stiffness, and crepitus. Radiographs taken while standing assess joint alignment and degenerative changes under physiological load, providing essential information for diagnosis and management.

Key learning point: For chronic knee pain with suspected osteoarthritis, standing plain radiography is the most appropriate initial investigation to assess for joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation.
Image Description:

X-ray knees (AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes of the left knee are seen, with marked medial compartment narrowing, surface irregularity (indicated by red line), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and osteophytes (red overlay). Additional findings include a subchondral cyst (blue overlay) at the lateral edge of the tibia and medial subluxation of the femur (indicated by dashed arrows). Only small intercondylar eminence osteophytes are seen on the right (yellow arrowheads).

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman presents with an 8-month history of right knee pain that worsens after walking or climbing stairs and improves with rest. She experiences mild morning stiffness and stiffness after prolonged sitting, which subsides within 15 minutes. She is otherwise healthy. Examination shows mild joint effusion without erythema or warmth. Laboratory results show normal C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Joint fluid




 WBC
170/μL
< 200/μL



Knee radiograph: Joint space narrowing and bony outgrowths
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis manifests with chronic joint pain that worsens with weight-bearing activities and improves with rest. The brief morning stiffness and activity-induced stiffness are characteristic features. Radiographic findings, such as joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation, result from degenerative changes due to mechanical wear and tear. Normal inflammatory markers, including C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, support the absence of a systemic inflammatory process. The combination of clinical presentation, imaging, and laboratory data aligns with osteoarthritis of the knee.

Key learning point: Osteoarthritis is characterized by joint pain aggravated by activity, relieved by rest, and X-ray findings of osteophytes and joint space narrowing, with low leukocyte count in synovial fluid.
Image Description:

X-ray knees (AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes of the left knee are seen, with marked medial compartment narrowing, surface irregularity (indicated by red line), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and osteophytes (red overlay). Additional findings include a subchondral cyst (blue overlay) at the lateral edge of the tibia and medial subluxation of the femur (indicated by dashed arrows). Only small intercondylar eminence osteophytes are seen on the right (yellow arrowheads).

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with symmetric polyarticular involvement, prolonged morning stiffness, joint warmth, and elevated inflammatory markers. The patient's brief morning stiffness and normal inflammatory markers suggest a degenerative rather than inflammatory process. Joint fluid analysis shows a white blood cell count within the noninflammatory range, unlike the higher count seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Gout usually presents with sudden, severe joint pain, swelling, and redness, often affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The patient's chronic knee pain, mild effusion, and normal inflammatory markers contrast with the acute presentation of gout. Radiographic findings of joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation suggest a degenerative process, not gout.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudogout is associated with acute joint inflammation, pain, swelling, and warmth. The patient's chronic pain pattern and minimal morning stiffness are inconsistent with pseudogout. Radiographs in pseudogout typically show chondrocalcinosis, not joint space narrowing and bony outgrowths. The synovial fluid white blood cell count is lower than expected in pseudogout.

questions.text: You are seeing a 65-year-old woman with a history of obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes who presents with left hip and anterior left groin pain that has gradually worsened over the past 2 years. The pain is aggravated by walking and relieved by rest. She reports no radiation of pain to the leg, low back, or buttocks, and denies leg weakness, numbness, or tingling. She does not recall any trauma and has not experienced fevers, night sweats, or unintended weight loss. Which one of the following maneuvers during physical examination is most likely to reproduce her pain?

choices.text: Direct pressure over the lateral hip.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the hip is a nonspecific maneuver that may be well tolerated even with severe hip osteoarthritis because it does not effectively move the femoral head toward the acetabulum.

B) INCORRECT:

Straight-leg-raise tests are more likely to elicit pain related to lumbar radiculopathy by stretching or impinging vulnerable nerves.

C) INCORRECT:

Direct pressure over the lateral hip may aggravate pain caused by greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) or gluteus medius tendonitis but does not affect hip pain that is due to osteoarthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Straight-leg-raise tests are more likely to elicit pain related to lumbar radiculopathy by stretching or impinging vulnerable nerves.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's hip pain can be reproduced by internal rotation of the hip with the leg extended — a maneuver that narrows the space between the femoral head and acetabulum.

The FABER test would be another reasonable physical examination maneuver in this case, if the patient can tolerate it. While the patient is lying supine, the leg is placed in a figure-4 position (Flexion, ABduction and External Rotation of the affected leg, so that the ankle of that leg is on top of the opposite knee). Anterior hip/groin pain or limitation of the range of motion constitutes a positive test and indicates hip pathology, although a FABER test can also cause pain with iliopsoas spasm or sacroiliac disease (in the contralateral buttock). Patients with advanced hip osteoarthritis may not be able to tolerate a FABER test.

Key learning point: Osteoarthritis of the hip causes anterior hip and groin pain that can be reproduced by internal rotation of the hip.
questions.hint: Anterior hip or groin pain that worsens with weight-bearing or exercise and improves with rest raises suspicion for osteoarthritis, the most common disorder of the hip joint.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents with a 4-month history of progressive bilateral hip discomfort that is worse with activity. He reports difficulty rising from chairs and notes the pain is located in both groin regions, with the right side more symptomatic. Physical examination shows an antalgic gait, limited internal rotation of both hips that is worse on the right, and tenderness over the right greater trochanter. Vital signs are normal. Plain radiography of the pelvis is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Oral NSAIDs and outpatient orthopedic referral
Arthrocentesis of the right hip joint

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic features of hip osteoarthritis, including groin pain, activity-related symptoms, antalgic gait, and limited internal rotation. Corroborative x-ray findings include joint space narrowing, femoral head and acetabular sclerosis, subchondral cysts, and osteophytes. First-line management consists of NSAIDs for symptomatic relief and orthopedic referral for comprehensive evaluation and long-term management planning.

B) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is not indicated in patients presenting with typical osteoarthritis. Joint aspiration is primarily reserved for patients with acute arthritis to assess for crystal arthropathy and rule out septic arthritis. This patient's bilateral presentation, chronic course, and classic osteoarthritic features make infection or acute crystal arthropathy unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular corticosteroid injection is a treatment option for osteoarthritis but is typically reserved for patients who do not respond to first-line oral NSAIDs. Initial management should begin with oral anti-inflammatory medications before considering procedural interventions.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI is not indicated in patients presenting with typical osteoarthritis and would not change emergency department management. Advanced imaging is reserved for cases in which there is clinical uncertainty or suspicion of other pathology, such as osteonecrosis or fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

Urgent orthopedic consultation is not indicated for chronic osteoarthritis without acute complications. This patient can be managed with conservative measures, outpatient specialist referral, and evaluation for potential surgical intervention if conservative management is unsuccessful.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of worsening right knee pain. The pain is a deep ache, exacerbated by walking and climbing stairs, and improves with rest. She reports approximately 20 minutes of morning stiffness in her knee. She has not found relief with acetaminophen and was unable to tolerate oral naproxen due to dyspepsia. She participates in physical therapy. She has a history of hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Examination shows bony enlargement, crepitus, and medial joint line tenderness. Radiographs confirm moderate osteoarthritis. She agrees to an intra-articular glucocorticoid injection. Which of the following is the most appropriate information to provide regarding this intervention?

choices.text: Improves joint lubrication by restoring synovial fluid viscosity
Provides significant pain reduction for several weeks to months
Reduces the ultimate likelihood of requiring surgical intervention
Slows the progression of cartilage degradation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restoring synovial fluid viscosity is the proposed mechanism of action for viscosupplementation, which involves injecting hyaluronic acid preparations into the joint. Glucocorticoids do not improve joint lubrication or restore synovial fluid viscosity; their mechanism is based on reducing intra-articular inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

The primary benefit of intra-articular glucocorticoid injections is short-to-medium term symptomatic relief, with peak effects seen at 1–2 weeks and a duration of benefit that typically lasts from 4 to 12 weeks. The onset of action is typically within 24 to 72 hours. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections are a second-line therapy for osteoarthritis, indicated for moderate-to-severe pain, particularly when oral analgesics are ineffective or contraindicated. They work by exerting a potent local anti-inflammatory effect, reducing the synovitis that contributes to pain. This intervention does not modify the underlying disease course but can be an effective bridge therapy to improve function and allow for more effective participation in physical therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections are a tool for symptomatic management and do not alter the natural history of osteoarthritis. They do not prevent the progression of joint degeneration or reduce the long-term probability that a patient will eventually require a total knee arthroplasty. The injections may temporarily postpone surgery by controlling symptoms, but they do not change the ultimate need for it.

D) INCORRECT:

Although glucocorticoids reduce inflammation, which plays a role in osteoarthritis, there is no evidence that intra-articular injections are disease-modifying or slow the structural progression of the disease. In fact, frequent, repeated injections may have a chondrotoxic effect and potentially accelerate cartilage loss over time.
questions.hint: Their primary role of intra-articular glucocorticoids in osteoarthritis is to manage symptomatic inflammation, but they do not alter the underlying degenerative process.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with moderate osteoarthritis of his left knee presents with difficulty ascending and descending stairs. He is concerned about losing balance and wants to use a cane. On examination, he has mild discomfort on weight-bearing of the left leg but has no motor or sensory deficits.
Which of the following instructions is most appropriate for proper cane use to reduce discomfort and ensure stability while walking?

choices.text: Hold the cane in the right hand and advance it with the left leg
Keep the cane behind the left foot and move it only after the right leg passes
Use the cane in whichever hand is more comfortable at any time
Hold the cane in the left hand and alternate it with the right leg

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Proper cane use involves holding the cane on the side opposite the affected leg to maximize stability and reduce weight-bearing stress. For a patient with left knee osteoarthritis, using the cane in the right hand helps transfer weight away from the painful joint. Advancing the cane with the left leg reduces the load on the affected leg, enhances balance, and provides a broader base of support, leveraging upper limb strength to reduce strain on the compromised lower extremity.

Key learning point: A cane should be used in the hand opposite to the affected leg to provide better balance and support.

B) INCORRECT:

Proper cane use requires the cane to be positioned in front and moved with the affected leg. Keeping the cane behind the left foot delays support, prolonging weight-bearing on the painful joint. The cane should advance with the left leg to provide immediate mechanical support, reducing stress on the knee and aiding balance.

C) INCORRECT:

Using the cane based on comfort neglects the biomechanical strategy needed for optimal support. For left knee osteoarthritis, the cane should be in the right hand to redistribute weight away from the painful side. Arbitrary use can lead to inconsistent unloading of the affected leg, compromising stability and pain relief.

D) INCORRECT:

Holding the cane in the same hand as the affected leg does not effectively offload the painful joint. For left knee pain, the cane should be used in the right hand to support the affected side during the gait cycle. Alternating the cane with the right leg misaligns the support, failing to reduce the load on the symptomatic knee.
